climbs.name: West Face
climbs.fa: August 1978 by Alan Bartlett and Allan Pietrasanta

content.description: Climb the central crack and chimney system to the West Summit
content.location: The best descent option is by down-scrambling the SW Buttress to the roof described, then two to three 30m rappels will reach the bottom of the buttress.

climbs.name: West - East Summit Traverse
climbs.fa: 24 August 2009 by Chris Simmons and Carlton Swan

content.description: After climbing any route reaching the West Summit, traverse along the ridge (3rd with some 4th class steps) to a notch immediately below the East Summit.  One low 5th class pitch gains the East Summit

climbs.name: The Tangerine
climbs.fa: 10 July 2007 by Chase Wilson and David Wilson

content.description:
On the far left side of the west face, ascend 5.10a cracks to a large ledge. Continue up ledge and cracks up and left across the face (5.9) for another rope length until intersecting with the West Face Route at the top of pitch 2. Two more pitches of off-width and wide crack on the West Face Route leads to the summit block.

FA Trip report and thread can be found here:

supertopo.com/climbers-foruâ€¦

- Chris
content.location: The best descent option is by down-scrambling the SW Buttress to the roof described, then two to three 30m rappels will reach the bottom of the buttress.

climbs.name: West Chute
climbs.fa: July 1991 by David Harden and Don Palmer

content.description: From the basin south of the peak, climb a chute (5.5) that leads to a notch immediately SE of the East Summit.  climb through a tunnel in the ridge to a steep crack (5.7) on the east side to gain the summit block.
content.location: From the summit, downclimb/rappel to a notch immediately to the west. Descend the chute southwest, then traverse around the peak back to Dusy Lake.

climbs.name: Southwest Face
climbs.fa: July 1939 by Chet Errett and Don McGeein

content.description: No actual route information exists.  It appears that from the basin on the south side of the peak, 3rd-low 5th class line is possible to the right of the SW Chute.
content.location: From the summit, downclimb/rappel to a notch immediately to the west. Descend the chute southwest, then traverse around the peak back to Dusy Lake.

climbs.name: Southwest Chute
climbs.fa: Unknown.  Used to descend the first documented traverse in 2009.

content.description:
From the basin south of the peak, climb the obvious chute that leads to the notch immediately west of the East Summit.  One pitch of 4th/low 5th-class climbing gains the summit.

Its hard to believe that this line hasn't been climbed before, but the FA teams for the SW Face and the West Chute must have been interested in harder lines.  I thinks its very likely that they used this route as a descent.
content.location: Return the way you came.  This is also the best descent for routes reaching the East Summit.

climbs.name: Southwest Buttress
climbs.fa: August 1995 by Reese Martin, Sharon Reynolds, and Steve Reynolds

content.description: Start at the large ramp just left of the center of the buttress.  Low 5th class leads to a corner beneath a blocky roof.  Traverse right (5.6) to the crest of the buttress and follow 3 more pitches of 3rd and 4th-class climbing to the West Summit.
content.location: The best descent option is by down-scrambling the SW Buttress to the roof described, then two to three 30m rappels will reach the bottom of the buttress.

climbs.name: Northeast Face
climbs.fa: August 1933 by Frank Ferguson and A.C. Riedell

content.description: Ascend the obvious corner system (3rd and 4th class) to the ridge immediately east of the summit.  5th class climbing gains the East Summit
content.location: From the summit, downclimb/rappel to a notch immediately to the west.  Descend the chute southwest, then traverse around the peak back to Dusy Lake.

content.description: The K-L Route (aka the West Face, Right in Secor's guide) starts half-way between the West Face and the SW Buttress.  Look for right-trending corners and ramps for two pitches, then follow ledges and blocks up and left for three pitches to the West Summit.
content.location: The best descent option is by down-scrambling the SW Buttress to the roof described, then two to three 30m rappels will reach the bottom of the buttress.
